Expectation1: Communicate with pilots to provide instructions and updates
Situation1: A pilot declares low fuel on approach and needs immediate vectors to the nearest runway.
Expectation2: Recite and reflect on the Quran
Situation2: The community study circle convenes tonight to discuss verses the person has not yet read.
Story: The radio crackled with urgency as the pilot’s voice cut through: “Mayday, mayday, low fuel, requesting immediate vectors.” My hands hovered over the radar, heart pounding. Every second mattered. I relayed instructions, my mind racing to keep the airspace safe. But tonight was also the community Quran study circle, and I hadn’t read the assigned verses. I could already imagine the gentle disappointment in my mentor’s eyes, the expectation that I would come prepared, ready to reflect and share. My faith meant so much to me, and I longed for the peace those evenings brought. Yet, here I was, tethered to my headset, responsible for lives in the sky. The weight of both worlds pressed on me—one demanding unwavering focus, the other calling for spiritual devotion. I felt torn, caught between the urgent needs of the pilots and the quiet pull of my faith, unsure which voice to answer first.
